Award.AwardTitle: MRI Devlopment: Development of an Optical NanoKelvin Calorimeter
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the development of an optical calorimeter with nanoKelvin resolution which is estimated to improve upon the sensitivity of current laser calorimeters by more than three orders of magnitude, which will push the state-of-the-art in optical absorption measurements of 0.1 to 1 ppm (parts per million) to the ppb (parts per billion)region. This will allow the characterization of optical components with unprecedented sensitivity. Spectral resolution and measurements at 3 K combined with spatial resolution will yield unique information about the physical and chemical nature of native and laser induced material defects, which is necessary for the development of mitigation strategies. The new instrument will enable precision studies of optical/IR absorbance of materials used in low-temperature detectors with spectral, power, and spatial resolution, including the impact of adsorbed surface contamination. This will provide information on the position-dependent response of paramagnetic gamma-ray/particle detectors, which will result in lower operating temperatures for improved performance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We designed and constructed an optical nano-Kelvin calorimeter working at cryogenic temperatures. We successfully demonstrated a simulation-led design approach for a new type of cryostat with a "3K optical table." The cryostat is based on mechanical refrigeration. Thus it requires no liquid cryogens, conserving increasingly-expensive liquid helium resource. The cryostat is equipped with a tunable light source, which allows to record optical absorption spectra from the near infrared to the near ultraviolet spectral region. We demonstrated nano-Kelvin sensitivity. The resulting sensitivity in measuring trace absorptions is several orders of magnitude better than using all-optical techniques. The performance of the cryostat is in excellent agreement with our simulations, which allows for fast absolute calibration with high precision.

The device will be used for the characterization of ultra-pure materials important for high power laser components and nano-electronics and science. Several graduate and undergraduate students were trained in an interdisciplinary research environment at the intersection of low-temperature physics and optics. They also acquired skills in the design of scientific instrumentation using computer simulations. This background makes our graduates highly employable. The nano-Kelvin calorimeter generated interest in the commercial sector. We started to explore a possible SBIR (Small Business Innovation Research) proposal submission with a small company in the coming year.
